articles.author: RUSS BYNUM and AARON MORRISON
articles.description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. (AP) — A 21-year-old white man fatally shot three Black people in Florida with guns he bought legally despite once being involuntarily committed for a mental health exam, the local sheriff said Sunday.
articles.title: Sheriff provides the first details of how a white man fatally shot 3 Black people at a Florida store

articles.author: ROBERT YOON
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — With Donald Trump facing felony charges over his attempts to overturn the 2020 election, the former president is flooding the airwaves and his social media platform with distortions, misinformation and unfounded conspiracy theories about his defeat.
articles.title: Trump's drumbeat of lies about the 2020 election keeps getting louder. Here are the facts

articles.author: ROD McGUIRK
articles.description: CANBERRA, Australia (AP) — A United States Marine Corps aircraft with 23 Marines aboard crashed on a north Australian island Sunday, killing at least three and critically injuring at least five during a multinational training exercise, officials said.
articles.title: A US Marine Osprey crashes during drills in Australia, killing 3 and injuring 20, some critically

articles.description: MOSCOW (AP) — Russian authorities on Sunday confirmed the death of Wagner Group chief Yevgeny Prigozhin, putting to rest any doubts about whether the wily mercenary leader turned mutineer was on a plane that crashed Wednesday, killing everyone on board.
articles.title: Russia says it confirmed Wagner leader Prigozhin died in a plane crash

articles.author: DASHA LITVINOVA
articles.description: TALLINN, Estonia (AP) — Yevgeny Prigozhin smiled as a crowd of adoring fans surrounded his black SUV on June 24 in Russia’s southern city of Rostov-on-Don and cheered him on.“You rock!” fans shouted while taking selfies with the chief of the Wagner mercenary group, who was sitting in the vehicle after nightfall.
articles.title: Prigozhin's final months were overshadowed by questions about what the Kremlin had in store for him

articles.author: TODD RICHMOND
articles.description: BARABOO, Wis. (AP) — Arianna Barajas never thought of herself as the outdoors type. The daughter of Mexican immigrants who grew up in Chicago's suburbs, her forays into nature usually amounted to a bike ride to a community park.
articles.title: Environmental groups recruit people of color into overwhelmingly white conservation world

articles.author: NICK PERRY
articles.description: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand (AP) — The howling winds and perpetual darkness of the Antarctic winter were easing to a frozen spring when mechanic Liz Monahon at McMurdo Station grabbed a hammer.If those in charge weren’t going to protect her from the man she feared would kill her, she figured, she needed to protect herself.
articles.title: Women working in Antarctica say they were left to fend for themselves against sexual harassers

articles.author: JENNIFER McDERMOTT, BERNARD CONDON and MICHAEL BIESECKER
articles.description: In the first moments of the Maui fires, when high winds brought down power poles, slapping electrified wires to the dry grass below, there was a reason the flames erupted all at once in long, neat rows -- those wires were bare, uninsulated metal that could spark on contact.
articles.title: Bare electrical wire and leaning poles on Maui were possible cause of deadly fires

articles.author: GABE STERN
articles.description: RENO, Nev. (AP) — Santos Brizuela spent more than two decades laboring outdoors, persisting despite a bout of heatstroke while cutting sugarcane in Mexico and chronic laryngitis from repeated exposure to the hot sun while on various other jobs.
articles.title: Workers exposed to extreme heat have no consistent protection in the US

articles.author: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
articles.description: JACKSON HOLE, Wyoming (AP) — Rising trade barriers. Aging populations. A broad transition from carbon-spewing fossil fuels to renewable energy.The prevalence of such trends across the world could intensify global inflation pressures in the coming years and make it harder for the Federal Reserve and other central banks to meet their inflation targets.
articles.title: Global inflation pressures could become harder to manage in coming years, research suggests
